title: charlotte-cowan-takes-west-highland-way-memory-dad-kenny
story: Charlotte Cowan, from North Berwick is completing the walk, over five days, beginning on September .The -year-old is raising money for the townrsquos Edington Cottage Hospital, the place where her dad spent his last week.Charlottersquos dad Kenny Cowan was a support worker but a joiner by trade.Having lost her mother when she was a baby, Kenny raised Charlotte and her brother as a single parent with help from her gran and other family members.Charlotte, who lives on Lochbridge Road, had a great relationship with her dad.ldquoI was very close to him and practically attached to his hip when I was little, I would go everywhere with him, she told the Courier.ldquoHe was such a genuinely lovely guy, no one had a bad word to say about him.ldquoHe was a big personality in the community and was so well known and loved by many.Kenny played bowls for Dirleton Bowling Club, darts in North Berwick and was an honorary member at the townrsquos rugby club for  years.He had been suffering with a bad back on and off for years, thinking it was sciatica.But in October last year the pain was getting worse, to the point he struggled to get out of bed.Two months later, Kenny was told he had stage four aggressive cancer in his spine which had spread and nothing more could be done.It was his last wish to be able to go to Edington Cottage Hospital before he died.ldquoUp until his very last day he had lots of visitors in to see him, Charlotte said.ldquoI donrsquot think [the Edington] had ever known as many visitors.ldquoHe was laughing and joking and listening to his beloved Runrig.Kenny died on January , aged .Charlotte said: ldquoIt was extremely hard to lose him. It was one of the hardest things to go through but we take comfort in the fact he said he would always be watching over us and we had time at the end to get to say goodbye to him and he knew how loved he was.She has always wanted to walk the West Highland Way, being a lover of the outdoors and a keen hiker.ldquoFamily and work commitments always seemed to get in the way or I just thought it would be too expensive, she said.ldquoWhen my dad passed away, I wanted to do something for him it kind of gave me the push to stop putting it off and actually go for it.ldquoI just want to do something big in his honour.ldquoI would just like to raise a bit of money for the hospital as it is a huge part of our community.ldquoI went there with my children when they were young, my gran and nana spent time in there, and my dadrsquos dad spent his last days in there also.ldquoMy dad was so well looked after that I just wanted to give something back, say thank you for looking after my dad and the community so well.In terms of the walk she is excited about the challenge ahead, saying: ldquoI canrsquot wait for the walk, I know itrsquos going to be hard doing it over five days, which is an average of  miles a day. I just hope my feet are up to the challenge!Charlottersquos training is going well, having already completed practice walks on her route to check out the terrain.She has also walked up Ben Nevis and completed the Three Lochs Way in one day.ldquoI havenrsquot managed any consecutive days walks yet as with kids and work itrsquos not easy to fit in, she said. ldquoBut when schools go back in August, I will have a month to get last bits of training in. I do feel ready, though, definitely.ldquoA bad blister could ruin it all or an injury, but hopefully neither will happen. Irsquove just got to be as prepared as possible and keep my fingers crossed for the rest.Charlotte is not doing the challenge solo, with three walking friends going along with her.She said: ldquoSupport has been great, everyone is getting behind me and wishing me well and helping with sponsors. I really appreciate any money raised.She said a special thank you to her step-mum Heather, who met Kenny when Charlotte was  and later married him, saying: ldquoShe has been a huge support for me through everything and I really want to thank her for that.On her goals, she said: ldquoJust being able to give something back is all Irsquod like to achieve.ldquoWe will be celebrating with a big gin at the end! The feeling of achievement and knowing I will have done my dad proud will be the best feeling, though. He would probably have called me crazy for doing this as he did for a few things I had done, but I know hersquod be proud and thatrsquos all I want to do.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving CharlotteCowan or via the sponsor sheet at Charlottersquos work, Smithrsquos Pharmacy, North Berwick High Street.

title: dog-walker-stalker-sentenced-next-year
story: David Page followed and filmed the woman for over five years after he spotted her Labradoodle allegedly becoming overly-friendly with his greyhound-cross while out on a walk with his pet.Page, , used a GoPro camera, a mobile phone and a long-lens camera to intimidate the woman and her family when they took their dog out for walks in the town.The woman was forced to call the police and, after denying the allegations, Page, of Castle Street, eventually stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year.He was found guilty of causing fear and alarm to the woman and her family between January  and October  following the trial last July.He was also found guilty of a separate charge of using abusive language towards employees at East Lothian Council during a phone call on October , .Sherf Alistair Noble issued Page with a four-year non-harassment order banning him from approaching the woman and deferred full sentence to last week.However, when Page appeared in court, the sherf again deferred sentence on him to January next year.

title: great-music-tap-belhaven-brewery-hosts-300th-birthday-festival
story: The Belhaven th Birthday Bash features household names including Dougie Mac-Lean and Capercaillie, as well as up-and-coming bands such as Assynt and Kinnaris Quintet.The special event, which takes place in Dunbar on September , is being billed as a celebration of the best of Scottish music and beer.Gordon Muir, marketing controller and festival organiser, said: ldquoItrsquos not every year you get to mark a milestone as big as  years and so we wanted to celebrate this with Belhavenrsquos two loves, beer and Scottish music.ldquoBelhavenrsquos th Birthday Bash is the ultimate party for those fans and our loyal customers who enjoy nothing more than a few beers and great live music.ldquoWersquove plenty of things for the whole family to do, including storytelling and games for youngsters, selfie sessions and music masterclasses for the teens, and beer tastings and brewery tours for the adults.The main stage showcases the best in Scottish traditional music and top talent from Scotlandrsquos folk scene over the last three decades.Multi-award-winning Scottish contemporary folk band Breabach are joined by Highland outfit Tide Lines Niteworks, who have become renowned for their fusion of electronica and folk music and Elephant Sessions and Talisk ndash both winners of Belhavenrsquos annual bursary for innovation in Scottish music.Belhaven Breweryrsquos beers will be served from tap bars around the brewery grounds, including , a specially brewed birthday celebration pale ale. There will be food stalls and merchandise stalls.Meanwhile, the brewery gardens host family activities and music masterclasses.Gates open at am, with the first act taking to the stage at noon.The following day, the brewery is hosting an open day between am and pm.More information at belhaven birthday-bash

title: flexible-fundraiser-flips-along-belhaven-bay-help-charity
story: Hugh Panton literally went head over heels to help Friends of the Earth Scotland as he backflipped for a mile along Belhaven Bay.The -year-old, who lives just a mile from the beach, on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, told the Courier: ldquoI was graduating from the University of Aberdeen and wanted to do something a bit special.ldquoI have always wanted to do a fundraiser event but never really had the time when I was at university.ldquoI decided I would do something that capitalises on my skills as a flipping enthusiast and had a couple of ideas.ldquoI thought maybe I would try to do , flips in five days or something and then it just came to me to try to do a mile of flips.ldquoAt the time, it sounded quite ridiculous but I really wanted to try it.The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil spent three days last month working his way from west to east along the picturesque beach for the challenge, which took him about  hours to complete.Hugh, who has started work as an assistant countryside ranger at the Loch of the Lowes Nature Reserve, near Dunkeld, was not the only one on the beach, as he attracted curious glances from onlookers.Hugh, who studied geography at university, managed to raise more than pound, and said: ldquoI would go down to the bay and I go to the very far end where there are not too many people.ldquoAfter a wee while training before doing the event, people would be walking by and their heads just slowly started following me down the beach.ldquoThere were horse riders as well and the horses did not like it at all and I would have to wait for them to pass.The flips were broken down into blocks of five or  so Hugh could keep his bearings, with the talented tumbler completing about  flips over each of the three days ndash  in total.Kerrigan Bell, development manager for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Hugh decided to raise much-needed funds.

title: airshow-lifeboat-fete-gullane-games-musselburgh-festival-spott-fete
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do over Saturday and Sunday.Whether it is planes, boats, horses or much more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied - eventhe weather isnt perfect.. Scotlands National AirshowBIG crowds are expected to flock to the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune on Saturday as Scotlandrsquos National Airshow takes place.And as well as all the aircraft initially announced, there are some exciting new additions to the line-up for the airshow, which takes place between am and pm, with the aerial displays set to commence from .pm.Despite todays poor weather, organisers said this morningthat the Met Office forecast "showednothing to prevent the Airshow going ahead today as planned".A Wildcat HMA  maritime attack helicopter,  Catalina flying boat and a  North American T Texan training aircraft are among the newbies.Joining them in their debut at the airshow are a Second World War Soviet Yakovlev Yak- fighter, a Westland Scout helicopter and a de Havilland Beaver utility aircraft.Also in the mix at the airshow are a Goodyear Corsair FG-D US wartime fighter bomber, Canadian T- Silver Star jet and an American P Thunderbolt Second World War fighter, while five members of the Wings Parachute Display Team drop in.As well as all the new additions, the aerial entertainment programme includes the RAFrsquos Supermarine Spitfire, Hawker Hurricane and Avro Lancaster from the RAF Battle of Britain Memorial Flight, as well as the modern-day Typhoon fighter jet.Aerobatic display team The Blades will take to the skies along with the AeroSuperBatics Wingwalkers, both performing some breathtaking tricks plus, much, much more.Tickets can be bought online, by calling    or on the gate on the day. Visit nms.ac.uk airshow for more details.. North Berwick Leboat FeteTHERErsquoS plenty of fun on offer this Saturday as North Berwick Leboat Fete takes place.The event, which runs between .pm and pm, starts with a parade along High Street before the crowning of this yearrsquos Leboat Queen, Theodora Nikolova, by Lady Dalrymple.The fete at Elcho Green and West Beach then opens at pm, with ious stalls and games on offer and a raffle.. Spott FeteAFTERNOON tea, games for children, stalls and music are all promised at Spott Village Fete.Teas are served in the village hall, with the event held on The Glebe from pm to pm.. Gullane GamesA WEEK of celebrations s to Gullane as the annual Gullane Games kicks off on Saturday and runs until next Saturday .The opening day is packed with sport ndash featuring golf, football and hockey.The under-srsquo golf competition starts at am on the childrenrsquos course.Football for under-s begins at pm at Memorial Park and P- hockey gets under way at .pm on the astroturf.Sunday sees a village treasure hunt from pm at the Mallard Hotel. title: attempts-bring-bugs-back-john-muir-way
story: Charity Bugle Scotland aims to boost insect and bug numbers along or near the Dunbar-to-Helensburgh John Muir Way by encouraging wildflower-rich habitats at selected sites.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoThe UK has lost over  per cent of species-rich grassland since the s with dramatic declines in associated wildle including native bees, butterflies, hoverflies and beetles.Phase two of the pollinator project has recently been completed.There were  habitat sites in total that were seeded and rewilded, including four sites in East Lothian: Prestongrange Museum, by Prestonpans Cockenzie Primary School Longniddry Wood and at Waterston House, Aberlady.A new wildflower meadow was created on-site at Prestongrange Museum with help from the staff and volunteers Cockenzie Primary teachers and pupils lent a helping hand to create a bee garden in the school grounds and wildflower seeds were distributed to Waterston House to enhance their existing wildle garden and orchard. At Longniddry Wood, the charity worked with East Lothian Council to plant new bulbs and seeds.All of the habitats along or close to the John Muir Way were supported by funding from the Scottish Government and the Greggs Foundation, as well as the Central Scotland Green Network and the local authorities.Joanna Lindsay, conservation officer for Bugle Scotland said: ldquoCommunities all along the John Muir Way have contributed to enhancing their local greenspaces for wildle through this project and have learned about the importance of protecting our pollinator populations. Hopefully this time next year, walkers and cyclists using the route will enjoy seeing these sites buzzing with le.Roseanna Cunningham MSP, Environment Secretary, added: ldquoIrsquom pleased to support initiatives like this which help to create ideal habitats for our flora and fauna.

title: scottish-labour-leader-doctor-100-000-year-working-class
story: Leonard, who has endorsed calls to redefine class, said the label related to people are paid for their labour.A critic said this could mean company chief executives falling into this category, while Leonard has himself said a small business owner earning pound, a year would not.Since becoming leader in , Leonard has tried to sht the debate in Scotland from the constitution to issues relating to poverty, redistribution of wealth and public ownership.However, even his allies on the Left believe he has struggled to change the political weather, with the party slumping to fth place at the recent European election.Independence: is it the only way to save the Scottish Tories An important part of his political outlook is the belief in uniting people on the basis of their social class. In March last year he said: ldquoI am wedded to the John Maclean [a socialist during the Red Clydeside era] idea of rising with your class not out of your class. Trying to improve the outcome for everyone is something that appeals to me rather than asking how you can fulfil peoplersquos inidual aspirations."He also mentioned the word in his first conference speech as leader and claimed in December that ldquoworking class solidarity was the ldquoonly viable resistance to racism.Leonard mentioned ldquoclass on seven occasions in a recent piece and retweeted another article which focused on uniting working people across the country.In an interview with The Herald on Sunday in May, Leonard addressed his partyrsquos dismal result at the European election, but also he attempted to clary what he meant by class.Asked to define ldquoworking class in , he said: ldquoPeople who are paid for their labour.Put to him that this could include doctors, he replied: ldquoYes ... so long as they are not self-employed.ldquoYou can point to some people at the top end of that scale, but I think for the majority of people they may not see themselves socially as working class, but I would say that economically the vast majority of people in this country are working class.: New Scottish Secretary promised to help bankroll breakaway Tory partyAsked whether, according to this definition, a small business owner earning pound, a year would not qualy as working class, whereas a doctor on a six-figure salary who sells his labour would, he said:ldquoYes, because it is about your relationship with the economy. Itrsquos about where the balance of power lies in the economy, and whether you are an owner of wealth, or whether you are a creator of wealth.Leonard, who attended the Pocklington private school in Yorkshire on a scholarship, also addressed whether he considered himself to be working class: ldquoAs an elected politician, it is dficult to necessarily put me into a class. I am a servant of the people.However, asked the same question about his time working for the GMB trade union, the Old Pocklingtonian said: ldquoYes. And representing working class people to try and get justice.He added: ldquoThe construct of employment law in this country is still based on a master servant relationship.A Labour source said: ldquoBy Richardrsquos definition, someone employed as a chief executive would be considered working class. It seems flimsy.Paul Hutcheon: Ruth Davidsons chances of becoming FM depend on cutting Boris looseScottish Tory shadow finance secretary Murdo Fraser said: ldquoWhile Richard Leonard and his hard-left Labour cronies are tying themselves in knots over class, the rest of Scotland is just trying to get on with le.ldquoLabourrsquos obsession with class is rooted in bitterness and envy, and simply isnrsquot replicated anywhere across Scotland. Itrsquos no wonder their party is dying before their very eyes.

title: snp-government-agency-considers-closing-national-water-sports-centre
story: Sportscotland flagged up the closure of the decades-old facility at Cumbrae following a review and a decision is believed to be imminent. Staff have been told to turn down bookings.Scottish Tory MSP Brian Whittle said: ldquoThis facility is run by an SNP government agency ndash itrsquos their responsibility to make a success of this. Itrsquos simply not good enough to leave this axe dangling over the heads of staff.Sportscotlandrsquos role is to invest in the organisations and people who deliver sport and physical activity. It promotes an active Scotland and celebrates the benefits of sport north of the Border.A trust company owned by sportscotland also oversees three national centres ndash Glenmore Lodge, Inverclyde and Cumbrae ndash which offer opportunities to participate in ious sports.Cumbrae, an island whose sole town Millport has been a favoured retreat for generations of people from the west of Scotland, provides a range of activities including yachting, dinghy sailing, paddlesports, windsurfing and powerboating.However, a presentation to staff last month about a review of Cumbrae revealed that the centre is at risk.Scotlands Insider Guide: MillportThe update, obtained by this newspaper, highlighted its ldquohigh cost profile, as well as the ldquochanging needs of the sector.In the ldquoinitial options sections, the status quo was ldquoruled out by the Trust board. Reforms included redeveloping the existing site, relocation, closure, or the development of an alternative.The summary stated that the centre was set up to service the sector  years ago and that the island location is ldquoless desirable.It added that people want access to activities in ldquoclose proximity and claimed the cost profile is ldquounsustainable.In the ldquoclosure ndash what   section, sportscotland noted that staff would be informed following a formal decision.An email to staff after the meeting noted: ldquoI appreciate that the information was very dficult for staff to hear and is concerning for the future. I feel that you should be aware of the current status of the review regardless of the impact.It continued: ldquoWe are currently giving serious consideration to a new option of creating a Scottish National Sailing Academy in collaboration with RYA Scotland, Largs Yacht Haven, Largs Sailing Club and North Ayrshire Council.ldquoIf this were to be approved by the board then this would result in the closure of Cumbrae National Watersports Centre.It is understood a decision will be made by the trust board on August , with the outcome escalated to sportscotland later in the month.Regarding booking inquiries between November and February, staff were advised to turn them down by saying: ldquoDue to seasonal operational [changes] the centre will not be available during this time.The centre is popular with young people embarking on the Duke of Edinburgh Award and caters for school trips.Move over Tour de France: how Scotland could launch its own cycling tourFteen staff are employed at Cumbrae, in addition to  casual workers.West Scotland Green MSP Ross Greer said: ldquoClosure of the National Water Sports Centre would be a major blow to the community on Cumbrae. Irsquove raised the matter with the Scottish Government and hope that the Minister for Sport will intervene, recognising both the local and national importance of the centre.Whittle added: ldquoIf the nationalists are serious about improving health and activity, centres like this must play a pivotal role. Instead, it looks like the SNP is preparing to turn its back on it.A sportscotland spokesperson said: ldquoWe are currently undertaking a review of Cumbrae to determine the best provision of watersports in Scotland. We are looking at all options during the review and will make a decision by the end of the summer.

title: new-bed-boris-title-children-39-s-book
story: Eleanor had gone to the races dressed in a white jumpsuit. Unfortunately, only a couple of hours later, someone spilled red wine down her pristine outfit.Rather than cut her day short or rush home to change, Eleanor and her friends grabbed four glasses of red wine from the free bar. They went into the loos and tie-dyed her jumpsuit in the sink using the wine as dye to hide the stain.A few minutes under the hand drier and voila, she had an almost-new outfit. Think Jackson Pollock portraying a dusky pink sunset over a snow-capped valley. OK, I may be over-egging that slightly but, in truth, it didnt look half-bad.Most people can relate to Eleanors plight. It reminds me of the time a waiter accidentally dumped a plate of curry in my lap. Amid much profuse apologising, someone rustled up a spare pair of chefs whites and I was able to enjoy the rest of my meal looking like I had also cooked it.That is bested by a friend, though, who dined in an upmarket restaurant wearing tartan flannel pyjamas. It was her third outfit of the night. Shed started out in a posh frock, then ended up wearing a wine bucket.She recounts one of those comedy, slow-motion moments where the maitre d, who had been purposefully striding across the restaurant, unexpectedly found himself soaring through the air after tripping on an errant handbag strap snaking out from beneath a table.Attempting to regain his feet, the poor chap grabbed the nearest thing to hand. Cue the largely melted contents of an ice bucket being jettisoned towards my friend leaving her as drenched asshed gone over Niagara Falls in a barrel.:The secret regimes of celebrities and a toast to bevvy-themed namesHelp was at hand. Earlier that day, one of the waitresses had bought herself a pair of pyjamas from Primark. She offered them up to my grateful friend who was chittering with cold.My friend ed to drop off the freshly laundered pjs a couple of days later, along with a thank you note and gt. Talk about a dinner to remember.Goldilocks and his new bedYOU might have heard we have a new Prime Minister. As the latest incumbent of  Downing Street settles into his new pad, Boris Johnson is already facing criticism for reportedly spending thousands of pounds of taxpayers money on furniture, including a bed.A new bed for Boris  It sounds like the title of a childrens book. Which is somewhat appropriate as a man-child rocks up to run the country.You can picture the scene in the furniture shop with our political Goldilocks trying out all the beds until he finds one that is "just right" as in the fairy-tale with the three bears. There is a joke about Brexit, BoJo and making your bed in all of this, but Im simply too weary to deliver the punchline.Lets say the image that springs to mind is a lumpy futon that has been chucked out beside the bins and peed on by a passing dog.Relax hellip dont do itREGULAR readers of this column will know I have a penchant for dabbling in what could be loosely termed topical lestyle concepts. Or as my long-suffering husband prefers to call it: whatever-the-latest-nonsensical-fad-is-sigh.Already there has been a merry dance through Danish hygge , Scottish coorieand Finnish kalsarikannit .Now comes niksen, a Dutch relaxation technique which can be used as a method to combat work-related health problems, such as stress and burnout.The principle calls for the floating, rather than the focusing, of our thoughts. In short, permission to daydream. On paper, it sounds straightforward and blissful. Yet, as I have learned, doing nothing is not as easy as it looks. In fact, it is exhausting.Sample floating thoughts: "Beautul tree. Fluffy clouds. Oh, a plane! Where is that going  I wonder who is on board  That TV series Lost, the one where the plane crashed on a desert island, what was the ending about  Its been nine years and I still dont understand."Were they in purgatory that whole time  Was it a netherworld  Did they escape or die  Could I survive on a desert island  WhatI survived the plane crash but lost my glasses  Would I build a raft like Tom Hanks in Cast Away or wait for rescue :An ode to silly season and the unabashed joy it brings"What other films are set on a desert island  Robinson Crusoe. Swiss Family Robinson. Lord of the Flies. The Blue Lagoon. Oh, that makes me want chips. How long have I been doing this Niksen lark for now  That was a long two minutes hellip Enough, Im off to get pantsdrunk. And eat chips."

title: move-tour-de-france-scotland-launch-cycling-tour
story: After more than , miles of competition therersquos none today, bar the traditional finish on the Champs-Elysees which is left to the sprinters ndash the few who have survived the Pyrenean and Alpine torture ndash who still perhaps compete for their prize, the green jersey.But Le Tour isnrsquot just a magnicent and awe-inspiring athletic competition, itrsquos also an epic, spectacular and glorious prolonged advertisement for France, its culture, way of le and its countryside. Sponsors line up to support it and fund the teams ndash as Jim Ratclfersquos Ineos has done, taking over from Sky ndash while millions of tourists, and not just bike fans, crowd the routes, cling to the mountainsides, stay in hotels, drink in bars and cafes, and spend money on food and gts. Itrsquos a euro bonanza.Anyone who has seen the Tour live will have lasting memories, although the riders will have come and gone in seconds, starting in the hours before when the y sponsorsrsquo caravan comes through throwing out gts like T-shirts and sweets to the discarded ridersrsquo water bottles retrieved from the leading groups and the peloton, to the reminiscences afterwards, the photographs and the conversations in the town square bistros.But eventhe competitors at the heart of the event have bypassed quickly the large screens inside and outside will have been following on TV. From the cameras on the backs of motorbikes as they weave up and down the field to those in the helicopters overhead which donrsquot just capture the agony of the event below but the grandeur of the peaks and chateaux, to the eye-catching little tableaux put on by every village and town the route cuts through, from straw bales spelling out a message to massive art structures, down to sprayed support for a favourite rider on the roads.Ron McKay: Socks and dregs and rock n roll, beach le, the royal prerogative and the cautionary tale of a fat man slimmedSo why canrsquot we do it here  Why canrsquot we mount a race which will put Scotland at the forefront of the worldrsquos attention and which would pull in millions in sponsorship cash and tourist euros, dollars and yen and do more for the country in a year than VisitScotland. After all, Yorkshire piggy-backed on a Le Tour start and launched its own bike race ndash it is a real point of conversation for cycle fans and ordinary punters.And just think ndash even on a good day in Bronte Country, Yorkshire hasnrsquot a patch on bonny Scotland.As well as the sponsorship, the TV rights and spin-offs, French towns and cities compete for Le Tour to start and finish in their town or city, from around pound, to pound,, although this year Brussels is thought to have paid around pound million for the Grand Depart there.As with so many great ideas, the women have got there first, and this yearrsquos three-stage Womenrsquos Tour of Scotland sets off from Dundee on August .So surely, with so much wonderful scenery to celebrate and so much international exposure to be enjoyed, a full professional Tour along the lines of the French extravaganza is long overdue To encourage the Scottish Government to take this idea and run, or rather pedal, with it, wersquove devised our own -stage tour, showing off the best of the country.Wersquove also borne in mind that wersquove had to miss some worthy parts out because the infrastructure canrsquot now support the tour caravan, the dozens of cars and vans, the number of beds needed for riders and support, as well as the thousands of people who will drive there and line routes, supporting the riders.There would be intermediate sprints for prizes, also for hill and mountain wins, as well as prizes for the most combative rider of the day.As well as a yellow jersey for the winner there would also be inidual awards for the king of the mountains, a green jersey for the best sprinter, judged on points, and also an award for the young rider ndash under  ndash of the tour, judged on placing.Obviously, the roads involved would be closed for the duration of the lead-up to the stage and its aftermath. So here it goes, the Tour DrsquoEcosse is off ...Day OneThe Tour leaves from Glasgow and heads south to Girvan, across to New Cumnock, through Kilmarnock and back to Glasgow  kilometresDay TwoDepart from Glasgow, down through Clydebank and up along the side of Loch Lomond before the long climb to Crianlarich and the push to Glen Coe, Ballachulish and Fort William. Just over  kilometres.Day ThreeIn the shadow of Ben Nevis the tour heads to Spean Bridge and Invergarry, before a left-hander towards Morvich and Dornie before ending at Kyle of Lochalsh. A shorter stage, some km, but a punishing and rewarding one.Day FourItrsquos a tour of Skye. From Kyle across the bridge and through Broadford, Portree, up through Skeabost and round past Dunvegan, down through Sligachan and back to Kyle. kmDay FiveKyle to Inverness through Achnasheen and Dingwall. A stage of unexpected ndash and for many completely unknown ndash beauty. kmDay SixFrom Inverness down the Apast Aviemore and over the Pass of Drumochter, on to Dalwhinnie and Pitlochry, then across to Bridge of Cally and Blairgowrie, and on to Dundee. km.Day SevenTime trial from Dundee to Perth. km of predominantly flat going ndash one for the speed merchants.Day EightFrom Perth to Crieff, then Gleneagles, west to the Trossachs and finishing at Stirling. A stage of real iety and beauty. kmDay NineLeaving Stirling the riders head to Hamilton, the Biggar and up through Penicuik the Pentlands, to Musselburgh then Edinburgh, by way of Leith. kmDay TenThe last day. The survivors do a circuit of Edinburgh of km culminating in a sprint at the top of the Royal Mile or, for the yellow jersey, a perambulation round the sights of the capital.How does Le Tour work :: The winner is the rider who completes the course in the shortest time. So much so obvious. But hewonrsquot do it without the assistance of the seven other riders in the team and the technical back-up.:: Each team has a nominated leaderwith the other riders as domestiques, specialist sprinters or climbers , the workers who are at the service of the leader, chasing down breakaways or delaying the pack , leading pursuits, sheltering the boss from the winds, dropping back to help him hersquos in trouble, getting him drinks and feeding gels from the team cars.:: Each stage has intermediate sprints ndash and or climbs ndash which are sponsored with prizes and points for a half dozen or so riders. Itrsquos the same for the first few riders at the stage end, with the addition of a time bonus for the winner, usually six seconds over the rest.:: At the end of the tour the rider with the most sprint points wins the green jersey, the top climber wins the polka dot jersey, the overall winner the yellow ndash although in Tour DrsquoEcosse wersquoll go for a saltire on navy blue.:: It isnrsquot just an inidual race ndash teams are rated according to their combined times, with prizes. The teams are sponsored, in most cases by more than one company.:: The prize pot in Le Tour is relatively modest ndash when compared with Wimbledon or The Open ndash with a total of around pound million to be won, which the  teams and the  riders are competing for.:: The overall winner in the GC, the general classication, takes away pound, but, traditionally, splits the money with the seven other team members.

title: davdid-mundell-holyrood-election-pivotal-determining-future-independence-vote
story: Mr Mundell, who was replaced as Secretary of State for Scotland earlier this week as part of new Prime Minister Boris Johnsons Cabinet reshuffle, said that securing a unionist majority at Holyrood would prevent another vote on the issue from being held.And he said that Mr Johnson must give his backing to Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson - who did not support him during his campaign to succeed Theresa May at Number .:David Mundell warns Boris Johnson of risk to Union from no-deal BrexitIn an exclusive interview with the Scotland On Sunday newspaper, Mr Mundell said: "Theres nothing inevitable about having a second independence referendum, and certainly not in the short term."I do think that the  Scottish Parliament elections will be a pivotal moment."I regret that, because those elections should be about the Scottish Governments record on health and education and drugs and all the rest of it, but you can already see the direction of travel, that it is effectively going to be a referendum on a referendum."He added: "Its a very clear message that the way to stop another independence referendum is to ensure a unionist majority in the Scottish Parliament in , so that involves Boris backing Ruth to deliver.":Boris Johnson to meet Ruth Davidson as relations with Scottish party sourMr Mundells successor at the Scotland Office, Alister Jack, said that the UK Government would reject any request by the Scottish Government for a Section  Order, which would transfer powers to Holyrood so that a referendum could take place.Asked whether such a request would be accepted, he said: "Absolutely not. We decided that in ."

title: issue-day-ivy-opens-glasgow
story: The original is a celebrity magnet Always has been, since it first opened its doors in Londonrsquos Covent Garden in  as an unlicensed Italian cafe in the heart of theatreland. Now it remains a haunt for anyone who is anyone, from Brad Pitt to Kylie Minogue.It has crept where There are brasseries in locations such as Dublin, Manchester and Edinburgh and now Glasgowrsquos Style Mile is the next hotspot in The Ivy expansion.It will be open seven days a week and can accommodate around  guests.Whatrsquos on the menu The Buchanan Street restaurant will offer all day, brunch, breakfast, desserts, drinks and vegetarian and vegan menus. Among the offerings, there is even an afternoon tea selection with prices starting at pound. for a basic cream tea. Afternoon tea is pound. and you can add champagne for pound..The food on offer includes everything from classic dishes, steaks and fish and chips, while pancakes are a highlight of the brunch menu.Other dishes include lobster linguine and chargrilled halloumi with padroacuten peppers. The kitchen will be overseen by head chef Brian Scanlan.James Corden likes The Ivyrsquos shepherdrsquos pie He tried to get a table at  to celebrate working in the West End, but couldnrsquot get in the door, trying again in his late s when Gavin  Stacey had become a hit.ldquoI called up to ask for a table at pm on a Saturday night. I got it. That was a big moment, he said, adding that when he first dined there, he was ldquorelieved to see things like shepherdrsquos pie on the menu as ldquoit immediately made me relax.The Ivy sparked passion between Brad Pitt and Dawn French Dawn told the book, The Ivy Now - which shares some of the legendary restaurants fecircted recipes and memories of celebrity diners - that when she saw Brad dining with Terry Gilliam, she wrote the Monty Python star a note that said: ldquoMake Brad kiss me ashe adores me or I will kill your family. Love Dawn.An hour or so later, Brad grabbed her and kissed her to the surprise of all around, saying: ldquoHey Dawn, great to see you. God you look gorgeous. I can see yoursquore busy right now, but is there any chance we can hook up again  I would soooo love that, can I call you...Please !Then he waved and was gone.Dawn added that when she turned to her fellow diners, including Jenner Saunders, their jaws were "on the floor".Will Brad be available in the Glasgow restaurant Who knows  Hersquos no stranger to the city, having filmed part of World War Z to Glasgow in  and itrsquos sure to be a celebrity draw in Scotland.A party to celebrate the opening last Monday night attracted songstress Amy Macdonald and Judy Murray.Lauren Bacall was very Lauren Bacall-like While dining with Jude Law and his then partner Sadie Frost, Ms Bacall lit up a Marlboro Light, despite smoking being banned in the restaurant at the time. Sadie recalled that very soon, a ldquovery nervous waiter was hovering at our table, very politely asking Ms Bacall to please put out her cigarette. But the reply was to the point: ldquo**** off she told him.And he did.

title: trans-people-powerless-face-moral-panic-existence
story: Trans people and our allies were undoubtedly disappointed when the Scottish Government announcement on Gender Recognition Act reform stated that there would be further consultation on a draft bill.This is not because we donrsquot think careful consideration of this issue is important. It is because of what has happened in the  months between the original consultation closing and this announcement.We have seen a massive increase in hostility towards trans people, and conversations that seem to indicate that a vocal minority are much more concerned with trying to reduce our existing rights and social acceptance, rather than constructive dialogue about gender recognition reform.Read more:Trans Scots suffering abuse in wake of GRA debateIt is our sincere hope that as with the Equal Marriage legislation, this consultation focuses on the technicalities. There will be plenty of areas up for discussion: how long should a trans person have been living in their gender before they are eligible to apply  Is a period of reflection a useful safeguard  Should applications be limited to over s  We donrsquot believe anyone should be deemed as transphobic for expressing dfering views to our own on such issues.But it is understandable that many fear some people will use this second consultation to oppose trans equality more broadly. The last  years has seen our rights improved based on two key principles: that how the government and services treat trans people must reflect our lived identity, not the bodies we were born with, and that trans people deserve adequate privacy about our gender history. Newly championed calls to insist we must disclose our biological sex at birth in all circumstances totally undermine existing UK law, and the rulings of the European Court of Human Rights.Read more:Scottish Government accused of pandering to bigots over GRA delaysTrans people are not being unreasonable in objecting to such attempts to roll-back our existing rights. Being trans does not make someone delusional, a paedophile, a homophobe or a misogynist and calling us those things is not reasonable debate.At just .% of the population, and with no trans MSPs or senior journalists, trans people feel powerless within a moral panic over our existence. Letrsquos please have a conversation about gender recognition reform, without attacking existing trans rights.

title: snp-women-39-s-convener-criticised-insisting-canadian-trans-woman-jessica-yaniv-39-female-predator-39
story: A report in Edinburgh Universityrsquos journal Scottish Affairs, claims ldquoa profound conceptual change in our understanding of what it means to be a woman or a man has been taking place ldquowithout due diligence, democratic oversight or scrutiny.The paper looks at policy changes in prisons and proposed changes to the census, as examples of ldquopolicy capture by influential lobbying groups. The authors, Dr Kath Murray and Lucy Hunter Blackburn argue that in both cases, policy-makers, overly influenced by advocates for the rights of trans people, failed to consider how allowing people to self-declare their gender might affect other groups. ldquoThe analysis hows how decision making has been directed towards the interests of one specic interest group, to the detriment of another, women and girls, they state.Catriona Stewart:Trans rights questions in Yaniv male genitals waxing case must be answered in ScotlandA small number of influential actors appear to have secured a monopoly on how sex and gender identity are understood within Scottish policy-making.The report is not critical of the actions of LGBT groups in lobbying government. "Lobbying in good faith on behalf of a particular interest group is a legitimate activity in a democracy," the authors state.But they claim government should weigh and balance the needs of all interest groups and this has not been done. An example, they say, is the failure to consider whether gender self-ID policies might be "open to abuse by iniduals with malign intent, irrespective of gender identity". The authors say "there is evidence to suggest that failing to anticipate such abuse is naiive".The article concludes that the Scottish Government should review the adequacy of its institutional safeguards against well-organised lobbying.A spokesman for the Government said the Scottish Government was developing guidance to help realise the rights of both women and trans people and Cabinet Secretary for Equalities Shirley-Anne Somerville had reopened a consultation on its proposed reforms to gender recognition laws."The Cabinet Secretary said the Scottish Government would consult later this year on a draft Gender Recognition Bill, and this would include a full Equality Impact Assessment," the spokesman added.Read more:Gender self-ID law could run out of timeBut the gender reform debate has been a contentious topic even within the SNP government. This continued last week, when the SNPs National Womenrsquos and Equalities Convener Fiona Robertson faced signicant criticism online, including from SNP supporters, after she described a controversial Canadian trans activist as a ldquofemale predator and said Jessica Yaniv should not be misgendered.Yaniv is a transwoman who has been pursuing a number of businesses offering waxing services to women, after they would not offer the same service to her, because she is male bodied. Feminist campaigners say women should not be legally required to provide intimate services to a male-bodied person who declares they are a woman.Catriona Stewart:Trans rights questions in Yaniv male genitals waxing case must be answered in Scotlandn a debate on Twitter, Ms Robertson insisted Yaniv was a ldquofemale predator and that such people often ldquoused their womanhood as a way to access victims. But critics have accused her of being an apologist for male violence.When the Herald approached Joan McAlpine MSP, she said she had been lsquoinundatedrsquo with messages from female party members who disagreed with the women and equalities convenerrsquos comments. ldquoWhile there are female predators, they are exceptional," she said.Ms McAlpine said Ms Robertsons offence was then compounded by saying female predators use their femininity to harm other people. "That sounds like the assertion a menrsquos rights activist would make, to try and deny male violence by blaming women. No one with any understanding of violence against women and girls would say such a thing and it certainly isnt a feminist argument."She added: "Of course most men donrsquot commit violence against women and girls, but that doesnrsquot take away from the fact that around  per cent of sexual assaults are committed by men as are most violent crimes. Any analysis of society has to recognise that reality. How can you tackle the systemic nature of male violence against womenyou are saying women do this too "Read more:Gender self-ID law could run out of timeMs Robertsons comments were also criticised by Simon Fanshawe OBE, co-founder of Stonewall, who replied to her: ldquoYou surely understand that this is not about a lsquobad applersquo, itrsquos about precedent. If a male bodied person by self-id info can force women into what is effectively sex workon the basis of identity discrimination that is wholly bad for women.Ms Robertson later claried her statements online, accusing critics of misrepresenting her. ldquoTherersquos absolutely nothing in what Irsquove said that implies sexual violence isnrsquot a gendered phenomenon which is overwhelmingly committed by men, she said.

title: crafty-shetlanders-attract-new-breed-knitting-tourists
story: As Scotland carves out a lucrative niche as a chill tourism refuge from Europersquos deadly heatwaves, one canny entrepreneur has the market stitched up.Misa Hay is selling out her specialist knitting and hiking tours of cool, breezy Shetland. Her visitors do not just get to sport their knitwear on their holiday, they learn to make it too.The Czech fell in love with the islands on a school exchange and, after  years in Scotlandrsquos northern-most outpost, is passing on her love for its greatest craft to knitters from as far away as Japan, Texas and Tasmania.Ms Hay said: ldquoThey come through the summer because it is cooler here.ldquoOne of the attractions of coming here is that they get a chance to wear the knitwear they canrsquot put on at home because it is too hot.ldquoIncreasingly, we are hearing from people that they are escaping the heat of wherever they are from.Read more:Why scorched Europeans are heading to Scotland to chill outldquoSo they do appreciate the cooler climate. This will increase in the future ndash people will be looking for colder places, like Shetland or Scandinavia.Shetland Wool Adventures, Ms Hayrsquos niche tour company, charges nearly pound, for a deeply immersive experience,a week of knitting and walking and, most importantly, understanding the people and the culture of islands that gave the world both Fair Isle and Shetland Lace.Her business, mostly for the summer so far, is tapping in to two huge trends. First, her customers get to go somewhere that is not too warm. Second, they get to enjoy slow travel, to really get to know the people and place they are visiting.Ms Hay said: ldquoOur groups are small, generally  people, and they get to work with local people and they go hiking, exploring the outdoors as well.ldquoAs well as Shetland Lace and Fair Isle knitting are learning about the sheep in their natural environment, the tour is designed to immerse themselves in the culture of the place.ldquoThe priority for me is that when they come here is it not just a whistle-stop tour but they are meeting locals and doinglocal things.Shetland, after all, has been suffering bouts of extreme over-tourism, usually when a big boat full of tourists anchors at Lerwick, the islandsrsquo capital.Scottish tourism numbers rose from . million bed nights in  to .m last year, with the Highlands and Islands seeing particularly fast growth.Attractions in the north and north-east recorded record numbers in . Not including cruise visitors, there were , visits to Shetland in .A report for the local council worked out they spent pound. million.Ms May explained:ldquoWe have just hada big cruise liner in, the biggest one of the season, with , passengers on board. It is a stark contrast to our knitters.ldquoWe are getting a lot of these cruise liners, which are not about an inidual approach, unless they book a private tour when they are on board.ldquoShetland is really good at niche tourism, with small groups doing nature tours, photography and it feels less articial and more authentic.Such tourism is also more lucrative, Ms Hay believes. ldquoOne of the shops told me my visitors spend more than when there is a liner in. Cruise liner passengers do not spend much.Read more:Commonwealth Games voted top moment in Scottish tourismldquoThat is because our visitors are looking for things made in Shetland and want to spend their money locally. That makes tourism sustainable. They want to eat local food, they want to look for local books.ldquoI think it is quite rare to buy things that were made in the place you are because everything is so global.ldquoPeople love being able to buy something special from the place where they are holidaying, they appreciate it and are happy to spend quite a lot of money on it.So who are the knitting tourists ldquoOccasionally, we get men, but most of our customers are ladies, a mixture of ages, but predominately older ladies. However, we have had ones who are in their thirties.ldquoIt always amazes me that in their professional lives they could be lawyers or have big companies and they still todecide to come on a knitting holidayto Shetland.Ms Hay believes there is something relaxing about hand knitting with authentic, natural fibres. So people who de-stress with a craft hobby during their working week will happily do the same on their big annual break.Knitting continues to boom. So is knitting tourism. It has flourished in Iceland and Ireland, rivals to Shetlandrsquos craft traditions.It would take an accomplished Shetland hand knitter a week ndash or  hours ndash to make an authentic Fair Isle jumper. So Ms Mayrsquos clients do not necessarily manage to do the same on their trip.She finds they come prepared with their own woollens to wear on the island.ldquoOur tour is about learning the techniques, being inspired. Then they buy the yarn and they go home and finish their projects.And when they are finished they send pictures of their home-made Shetland knitwear back to the islands, a souvenir they have made themselves.

title: dr-punam-krishan-reality-life-scottish-gp
story: The brief transcript, which Dr Krishan posted on Twitter, read: "Patient: I dont want an Asian doctor. Receptionist: She is Scottish. Patient: She doesnt look Scottish. Receptionist: What do Scottish people look like  Silence. Appointment card taken. So proud of my team."The tweet went viral and Dr Krishan, , received messages from as far afield as Argentina, Colombia, Ghana, India, Canada and Australia. Six months later, she remains blown away by the reaction."It had an engagement of . million impressions across the world," she says. "I didnt expect it to be as global. It was such an overwhelmingly positive response."Dr Krishan, who works as a GP in the East End of Glasgow, has gained a raft of followers who enjoy her warmth, candour and thought-provoking posts on social media where she is an impassioned proponent about the importance of kindness."I always say to my medical students and trainees that learning the science is the easy bit," she says. "We can learn from textbooks, absorb the knowledge and spout that out. But it means nothingit is not delivered with compassion and care."It is a theme we come back to several times in our conversation. Hearing Dr Krishan talk about her love of being a GP, it is hard to believe she almost never took that path.The eldest of two daughters, she grew up in Glasgow and describes herself as being "raised on curry and Irn Bru". Her Indian-born parents arrived from Punjab in the late s. "We grew up in my dads corner shop," she says. "It was ingrained in us that education was the key to freedom. You were either going to be a doctor, lawyer, accountant or a failure."Medicine became an early front-runner thanks to her childhood family GP. "He was very much a role model for me from a young age because he was the core of our community," she says. "Everyone knew thatDr Kauser saw them, they would be OK."A seed was planted for the future Dr Krishan. "I loved the idea of being able to help and heal people in a community setting," she says. "I admired him and knew education was a must, but then I hit school and everything I loved was wildly dferent to the sciences."I enjoyed history and language and music and drama. I wanted to study English Lit, but I was edged into choosing medicine. My mum couldnt understand why I wanted to study English or drama.":Why we love Glasgows street artHer mother would regularly walk past the University of Glasgow, gaze longingly at its towering spire and tell her daughters that they would one day study there. "It was almost like she manested it," says Dr Krishan, a smile in her voice."It was one of her unfinished dreams. My mum had an arranged marriage. She was going to study medicine in India but couldnt because she came to Scotland to be married. Both my sister and I went to the University of Glasgow to study medicine. We are both GPs in Glasgow."On paper it sounds like a picture-perfect le trajectory, yet Dr Krishan reveals that in her teens, there was a point when she went off the rails."I was a nightmare for my mum and dad," she recalls. "Growing up, I was confused about where I truly belonged. Our summer holidays were always spent in India. I had very much my Indian existence at home, but all my friends were Caucasian."There were a lot of restrictions and being told: You cant do this you cant do that ndash what will the aunties think  which I found frustrating. I was always testing the boundaries. I got into trouble at school and was suspended on a couple of occasions."When I failed all my exams in third year ndash I got straight sevens in my Standard Grades ndash my mum said she was going to send me to India to finish my studies. She had lost hope. I was given one last chance to turn it around. That was a wake-up call."Dr Krishan, who attended Notre Dame High School, knuckled down and achieved the grades to study medicine. "It was after I became a doctor that I started to feel liberated," she attests. "Then I really felt my wings unclipped after I became a mum."The birth of her son Aarish, now six, provided another watershed moment. "I ended up on a ventilator in intensive care," she says. "My family were told that I didnt have long to live. What happened to me was a complete out-the-blue crisis point in le that gives you a scare."She had suffered a postpartum haemorrhage. "It was a freak, bleed-out episode," explains Dr Krishan. "I went into heart and lung failure, developed clotting issues and widespread sepsis."Afterwards, Dr Krishan experienced a le-changing epiphany. "Everybody around me tried to medicalise me," she says. "Everything was about maybe you need this tablet, when actually all I wanted was support and space to heal. I didnt want drugs to do that."I started exercising and eating food to nourish myself inside and out. It is amazing what insights being on the other side of that desk can give you. I ed to work a completely dferent doctor."Holistic care is something Dr Krishan regularly applies in her work as a GP. "I see a lot of poverty and patients living in social isolation, as well as drug misuse. It is quite a challenging population but equally it is a place where you can really make a big dference."Around  to  per cent of the things I see as a GP are lestyle-related medical problems. It has become my passion to focus more on the lestyle habits that people form, rather than just the -minute appointment model which is: How can I get you in and out  Can I give you a drug "She takes her patients on "Lidl walks" to share tips on what foods to avoid and how to make healthier choices. Last year, Dr Krishan and a colleague set up Glasgow Wellbeings, a public group where they share their "health hacks", which has grown to more than  members.Dr Krishan is married to a fellow GP. "He started off as an orthopaedic surgeon, but you cant live with me and not become a GP," she jokes. Her enthusiasm is clearly infectious, then. "I would sell it in a jarI could."She is currently writing a childrens health book and will make her presenting debut in a forthcoming BBC Scotland medical documentary series due out later this year. Dr Krishan also hopes to pen a memoir about her experiences working as a GP."My dream is to write books to help as many people as I can through informed and reflective storytelling in a bid to inspire and empower them along their wellness journeys. I want to bring my Eastern heritage and the wisdom that holds into my scientic Western practice.":Why we love Glasgows street artThe traditional role of a doctor advocates an evidence-based scientic approach to clinical care. It is important to maintain professional boundaries, yet Dr Krishan strongly believes that patients need compassion too.Such as instinctively hugging a patient who had been diagnosed with advanced bowel cancer. Two weeks later, after the man passed away, his family visited her to say thank you and tell her how much that hug had meant to him."Le has been kind to me in that it has taught me lessons ndash sometimes in the most brutal ways," she says. "I have been the vulnerable mum and I have ageing parents, so I understand the pain that brings. I have also lived as a troubled teenager trying to find my identity."With this man who was dying of cancer, I was helpless. There was nothing I could do. He knew that and I could see the fear in his eyes. It just felt so intuitive [to hug him] becausethat was my father or grandfather, I would have wanted somebody to reach out and say: Its OK, Im here for you."Follow Dr Punam Krishan on Twitter and Instagram at @DrPunamKrishan

title: letters-wrong-write-off-north-sea-oil-assets
story: In his dismissal of future oil revenues as any panacea for Scotland, Mr Hoskins will be aware of the suppression by successive Westminster governments of the  McCrone Report on North Sea oil, which said among many other things ldquoScotlandrsquos currency would become the hardest in Europe ndash Scots could possibly become richer than their southern neighbours ndash Scotlandrsquos budget surpluses would be so large as to be embarrassing. Of particular interest in the report was the identication of the West of Scotland as an area of special needs given its deprivation problems and how these might be improved with the revenue from oil. Westminster could very easily have created a special fund for Scotland at the time but no, the greed was too great and even the Britoil HQ based in Glasgow was closed and moved to London.Given the continuing problems of deprivation today and the recently reported huge number of drug deaths, it is quite simply unbelievable anyone living in Scotland would wish to continue under a Westminster regime that has consistently lied to Scotland and concealed the benefits of North Sea oil and it continues, as evidenced by Mr Hoskinsrsquo letter. That the price of oil has fallen and partially recovered is well known, but is it a resource of no real further benefit to Scotland  Consider the report in November  by Andy Critchlow, head of energy news for EMEA who, writing in The Dailysaid, without a single reference to Scotland, ldquothink what the UK would be like without the vast wealth generated by the equivalent of bn barrels of oil pumped from British territory over the past  years ndash there are up to bn barrels of oil still out there ndash North Sea oil should still give Britain the cash-generating power to defend its economy and the leverage to build new trading relationships overseas.Westminster wants us to believe oil is a millstone round our neck and there is a Scottish phrase for that: aye, right. It is unthinkable Westminster would set up a Scottish Oil Fund from oil and the vast gas revenues coming on-stream, especially as our new PM has the view that pound spent in Croydon is better than pound spent in Scotland. It is time to do it ourselves, they have had their chance and failed.Alan M Morris, Blanefield.THE letter by Robert Hoskins on the financial consequences of an independent Scotlandmakes some valid points, but not regarding the state pension being paid in a new Scottish currency.Current pensioners will continue to be paid in sterling .In fact, anyone still in employment with  years of qualying years will be treated similarly.Those with less than  years would receive a mixture of UK and Scottish Government pension.It would take at least a generation before a full Scottish Government pension, in whatever currency applies is paid.Jim McSheffrey, Gfnock.IN the House of Commons Boris Johnson askedScotland really wanted to join the euro, a currency which the Leave Campaign consistently dismissed as a joke during the referendum. TodayI bought euro for pound. Effectively the two currencies are at parity, whereas one could almost get euro for pound when the euro launched.I canrsquot help feeling that the euro joke is on me and I just donrsquot see what is funny. Perhaps Scotland should join asap. Maybe the poor English should do likewise. Things can only get worse.Ronald Cameron, Fort William.SINCE he took over leading the SNP at Westminster, Ian Blackford has used every exchange he has had with Government leaders to attempt to demean, insult, or be downright nasty to whomever he faces in the House.Never once has he attempted humour or wit to make a point. It has been the same mind-numbing and palpably phoney grievance-peddling, delivered in dead pan style, and antagonism, clearly meant to placate the zealots in his own party. He seems to relish in particular attacking the weak and wounded.Perhaps with a rumbustious new PM in office, ho will take no prisoners and gives as much he takes, Mr Blackford could try grown-up politics.Alexander McKay, Edinburgh EH.BOTH Private Eye, as reported by Alistair Grant Brexit chaos in Commons", The Herald, July  and Mr Grant are far too kind to Theresa May. Private Eyes blank page suggests she did not achieve anything she actually achieved much, but none of it worthy of praise.The ldquohostile environment for immigrants and the infamous vans with ldquoGo home emblazoned on them being driven through areas with ethnic minority populations hardly count as achievements of which any civilised human being would be proud. For a daughter of the church, they dont speak well of her Christianity.Mr Grant seems to accept that Mrs May kept her promise to end austerity. This would be laughable were it not so tragic for the victims. Figures published this week in Aberdeen show the continued rise in the need for food banks and the human stories of suicides resulting from the transfer to Universal Credit tell a very dferent story.I suppose Mrs Mays best hope, though not one to be welcomed by the rest of us, is that her successor so destroys livelihoods and social cohesion through his mad determination to tear the UK out of the EU, that herfailures fade into insignicance.Dr RM Morris, Ellon.WITH the usual sanctimony that we expect of the SNP, we hear time and time again that the party is against the privatisation of health care. And yet the SNP continues to use private hospitals to cut waiting lists, averaging , operations per year since . Perhaps instead of harping on about independence, Nicola Sturgeon should focus on ensuring we can all be treated timeously by the devolved NHS in Scotland.Jane Lax, Aberlour.Read more: Time to focus debate on the high costs of independence

title: helen-mcardle-proof-last---cats-dogs-good
story: In the face of what might seem like the impending doom of a Thelma and Louise-style exit from the European Union, the temptation to turn to wine, chocolate or simply despair is strong for many of us.Thankfully, scientists in the US have offered up a simple technique to lowering your cortisol level: playing with cats and dogs.Any cat owner struggling to get an unruly moggy into their box for a trip to the vet or retrieving a kitten from the top of a curtain pole might associate the experience with rocketing blood pressure, but research tells a dferent story.There is plenty of anecdotal evidence from people who praise their canine and feline companions as a source of comfort, amusement and relaxation. But the recently published findings of a study carried out at Washington State University show clear evidence of the mental health benefit to humans of pets.The randomised trial gauged  undergraduate students as they were split into four categories: petting cats and dogs looking at a slideshow of images of cats and dogs watching other people pet animals or being sat in a waiting room without animals where they were banned from using phones, reading or talking to one another - but on the upside, they were given pizza vouchers.The study, published in the American Educational Research Association, was set up to respond to evidence that levels of stress, anxiety, depressive symptoms and suicidal thoughts have increased among young people at university, and that these iniduals are more likely to get poorer grades or drop out.The researchers measured the participants cortisol - the stress hormone. Saliva samples were collected each morning after the students woke up and again to reflect pre- and post-test cortisol in the dferent categories.The scientists controlled for factors which might influence cortisol such as sleeping patterns, exercise, caffeine and alcohol intake. They also graded each student on their existing levels of stress, anxiety and depressive symptoms.The results showed that those who had hands-on interactions with cats or dogs experienced by far the steepest and longest sustained drop in their cortisol, indicating "momentary stress relief" had indeed occurred.Unfortunately, for those seeking a scientic answer to the thorny question, which is better, cats or dogs , the study draws a blank. Interactions with dogs and cats were counted as one category, although participants were actually allocated one or the other.The second-best results were achieved in the waiting room group - surely proof of the benefits of free pizza.So with turbulent times ahead, perhaps the Government should provide all citizens with a cat, a dog ndash or pizza

title: inverurie aiming to shine for the community
story: Judges will descend on Inverurie next week to assess the town for the coveted  Beautul Scotland awards.Inverurie Environmental Improvement Group has joined many others from across the country to celebrate more than  years of community improvement.The town is looking in fine colourful fettle for the judges arriving next weekAdministered by Keep Scotland Beautul - a member of the Royal Horticultural Society’s Bloom Federation - Beautul Scotland recognises the efforts of local authorities, communities and businesses which work tirelessly to improve their local cities, towns and villages.Entrants have together nurtured an astonishing number of plants, organised local environmental awareness campaigns and encouraged mass volunteer participation – all to improve the places they live and work in.Now the planters are blooming, the streets are clean and the community is ready to showcase its hard work to the Beautul Scotland judges.Three themes are examined during the judging - horticultural achievement,community participation and environmental responsibility - to discover which communities have been most successful in improving the attractiveness, cleanliness and sustainability of the places they care for.Winning communities will be presented with awards at a ceremony hosted by Dumfries and Galloway Council in September .The overall winner will be presented with the prestigious Rosebowl Trophy, while a number of discretionary awards will be presented for outstanding performance in areas such as bioersity, tourism, and community involvement. Some of the winners from Beautul Scotland  will go on to represent Scotland in the RHS Britain in Bloom Final in .John Glover, chair of Inverurie Environmental Improvement Group, said: “The IEI committee are delighted to be competing in Beautul Scotland  in the Medium Town category."This gives us an ideal opportunity to showcase Inverurie for its horticultural achievement, environmental responsibility, and community participation."Inverurie is a thriving town with many voluntary groups, social enterprises, schools, residents, businesses, public sector staff and elected members contributing to its success. This is an exciting time in the development of the town centre with the formation of the Business Improvement District last year."The cooperation of dferent community groups working together to improve and enhance the town centre will bring benefits for many years to come."Juliette Camburn of Keep Scotland Beautul said: “Communities, local authorities and businesses that enter Beautul Scotland have already made a massive contribution to ensuring that our country is nicer place to live, visit and work.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.cumbernauld-news webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Stewart Stevenson says the impact on business cannot be underestimated"  Review of parking charges is vital says MSPviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.cumbernauld-news webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  Forget Neil and Buzz, meet Scotland’s coosmonaut BuzzBò! viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“The entrant groups pull people together to build stronger communities and continue to make a massive dference to Scotland’s environment while having fun at the same time. I’d like to wish all the entrants the best of luck and look forward to celebrating all their achievements with them at the  award ceremony.”

title: forget neil and buzz meet scotland s coosmonaut buzzbo

Aldrin Jr. Neil had ancestral links to Scotland. The name derives from Buzz Aldrin, the second man to walk on the Moon, and the Gaelic word for cow, Bò.Alex Keen, launch specialist from Sent into Space, said: “Launching at Gilnockie Tower was a real treat. Not only were the team from VisitScotland a great bunch to work with but the countryside we crossed in pursuit of our payload is one of the most beautul and dramatic landscapes we’ve visited. “Once the Coosmonaut was back in our hands, we were genuinely sad to leave and head back to England.”A new tourism map highlighting Scotland’s links to space exploration and the first moonwalk has also been released.On the new trail...among the Scottish landmarks on the new VisitScotland map is the dark sky observatory in Dalmellington, Ayrshire.The Scotland is Out of this World trail is part of the new VisitScotland campaign of the same name.The trail features Scottish connections to each planet in the solar system, as well as fun facts and details of science centres and the best places to birthplace of th century science writer Mary Somerville who theorised that dficulties in calculating the position of Uranus may point to an undiscovered planet, which inspired the discovery of Neptune.Venus – Parton, Dumfries and Galloway: The resting place of th century physicist James Clerk Maxwell, whose name was given to Maxwell Montes, the planet’s only feature named after a man.The Scotland is Out of this World campaign marks the th anniversary of the Apollo  mission and US astronaut Neil Armstrong’s historic walk on the lunar surface.But it also celebrates the th anniversary of VisitScotland.Malcolm Roughead, chief executive, said: “For  years VisitScotland has helped position Scotland as a must-visit destination to audiences across the world.“It is therefore fitting that in our anniversary year we set our sights even further and travelled into space in what can only be described as a truly out of this world campaign.“Scotland is Out of this World offered the opportunity to delve into the past and celebrate the country’s contribution to space exploration and its ancestral links to one of the greatest moments in history.“The new trail reveals some of the country’s stellar attractions and locations to visit to firmly cement Scotland’s place in astro-tourism. “After all, our best views aren’t confined to our awe-inspiring landscapes but reach up high into the night sky above as well.”Ohio-born Neil Armstrong was proud of his Scottish heritage. The ancestral home of Clan Armstrong is Langholm in Dumfries and Galloway and in  he become the town’s first and only Freeman.Travel guide publisher, Lonely Planet, has identied dark skies as a tourism trend for .VisitScotland’s Insight team has created a research paper examining the opportunities for tourism businesses to engage with the trend.Scotland is home to two International Dark Sky Parks, Galloway Forest Park in Dumfries and Galloway and Tomintoul and Glenlivet in Cairngorms National Park. Isle of Coll is also a Dark Sky Island and Moffat a Dark Sky Town.To view the map, visit static.visitscotland pdf out-of-this-world-trail.pdf.First man on the moon’s Scottish linksNeil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins formed the three-man NASA mission which set off on July , , to land on the surface of the Moon. On the evening of July , Armstrong and Aldrin touched down on the lunar surface. Armstrong took “one giant leap for mankind” when he became the first person to walk on the moon.Three years after that historic moment, the Ohio-born NASA astronaut who commanded Apollo  took another “small step” into the history books in Langholm, the ancestral home of Clan Armstrong.There, in the “Muckle Toon”, he became the first and only person to be awarded the freedom of the burgh.Accepting the honour, he told the audience: “It’s said that the most dficult place to be recognised is in one’s own home town. And I consider this, now, my home town.” Many craters on the Moon and Mars are named after Scottish scientists. They include Aberdeen astronomers Arthur Mee and Sir David Gill and Edinburgh mathematician John Napier of Merchiston.The average distance from Earth to the Moon is about , miles .

title: inverurie scouts aiming to raise bags of cash for new air ambulance
story: Big-hearted Scouts are hoping to raise vital cash for a new air ambulance by collecting empty crisp packets.Inverurie Scout Group is supporting the ‘Crisps for Helimed ’ campaign to help raise cash for a second le-saving aircraft for the North-east by .By collecting crisp packets for recycling and fundraising, it will help bring a new £ million air ambulance to Aberdeen in .For every  bags recycled, £ will be donated to the charity.Scout group volunteer Jackie McBeath said: “This will be a great local asset for le-saving services in our area that we are proud to support.“We are also very aware of the environmental issues affecting us globally and are delighted to be able to do a little to help the world we live in.”The idea came from Inverurie Scout Group Explorer leader Ross Couttie who had heard of the Helimed initiative and thought it was a good idea for the group which boasts more than  members from Beavers, Cubs, Scouts and Explorers.Jackie explained: “He got in touch with Crisps for Helimed  and ordered a box for collecting them. We have already asked all our members to start collecting empty crisp packets and are setting up a collection point in our Scout Hut.“We will be collecting all crisp packets including large bags and the multi pack bags as well as popcorn and other snacks bags.“We think that now is an ideal time for our members to start collecting as over the summer holidays people have more picnics and snacks especially in this gorgeous weather. “Inverurie Scout Group can’t wait to see how many we get when our section meetings start up again in August..The group has appealed to the local community to join in and drop-off off collections at the Scout Hut at section meetings duringterm-time. Those interested in helping can also contact the group via its Facebook page at InverurieScoutGroup and the team will arrange to collect them locally.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Sophie Miah has been traced safe and well"  Missing Kemnay girl Sophie traced safe and well viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"
